questions.text: What is epicolic node? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) LYMPHATIC DRAINAGE OF LARGE INTESTINE Lymph nodes are commonly grouped into levels depending on their location Epicolic : Located along the bowel wall and in the epiploicae Paracolic : Located adjacent to the marginal artery Intermediate: Located along the main branches of the large blood vessels Primary or terminal: Located on the superior or inferior mesenteric artery

choices.text: First organism in new born is coliforms and streptococcus
Chyme in jejunum contains many bacteria

questions.text: True about colonic organisms is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) NORMAL MICROBIAL FLORA OF INTESTINAL TRACT • At birth, the intestine is sterile, but organisms are soon introduced with food. • In the breastfed children, the organisms present in the intestine: Lactic acid streptococci and Lactobacilli

questions.text: Antiperistalsis is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) antiperistalsis is a feature of proximal colon.

questions.text: Mass movement of the colon would be abolished by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Auerbach’s plexus are situated between and innervates outer longitudinal and inner circular layers of intestine. They are primarily concered with peristalsis and destruction of auerbach’s plexus can abolish the movements of the colon.

questions.text: Which of the following is not degraded by colonic flora? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) lignin is not fermented by human colonic flora and attracts water and thus it is a bulk forming agent. Option A that is pectin is present in fruits and it is completely fermented in the intestine. Option C and D are starch and glucose which are readily fermented in the intestine and forms a part of our food.

choices.text: Usually venous blood flow affected first

questions.text: True about strangulation of intestine is (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Venous return is compromised before arterial supply in strangulated intestinal obstruction. Option C is wrong as blood flow is not normal in strangulation of intestine. Option D is wrong as gangrene is a feature of strangulated obstruction.

questions.text: Most common cause of hyponatremia in surgical practice: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The most frequent cause of sodium depletion in surgical practice is obstruction of the small intestine, with its rapid loss of gastric, biliary, pancreatic and intestinal secretions by antiperistalsis and ejection, whether by vomiting or aspiration. Duodenal, total biliary, pancreatic and high intestinal external fistulae are all notorious for bringing about early and profound hyponatremia.

questions.text: Best investigation for acute intestinal obstruction is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) among the given options X ray abdomen is the best method to diagnose intestinal obstruction as it can detect multiple air fluid levels and demonstrate step ladder pattern of the intestinal loops. Option D is wrong as ERCP has nothing to do with intestinal obstruction diagnosis. Option C that is USG can suggest but X ray is better than usg to diagnose intestinal obstruction. Option A that is barium studies are not usually used to diagnose intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: The most common cause of small intestinal obstruction is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) most common cause of intestinal obstruction is post-operative iatrogenic adhesions. Adhesions (60%) > Malignant tumors (20%) > Hernia (10%) > Crohn’s disease (5%).

questions.text: Acute intestinal obstruction is characterized by: A. Vomiting is common in duodenal obstruction B. Pain after each attack of vomiting is characteristic of ileal obstruction C. In colonic obstruction distension is common than vomiting D. X-ray erect posture is diagnostic E. Colicky pain to steady pain indicates strangulation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (A, C, D & E) Option A is correct as vomiting is one of the important features of duodenal obstruction . Option B is wrong as the pain and vomiting are not related to each other in intestinal obstruction. Option C is correct as in colonic obstruction there occurs colonic distension as colon is the most distendable part of GIT. Vomiting if at all occurs it occurs late in colonic obstruction. Option D is incorrect as X ray supine is diagnostic for obstruction. Option E is correct as in the beginning part of intestinal obstruction patients experience a colicky abdominal pain when the proximal segment causes increased peristalsis which tries to overcome the obstructed segment and when this is not possible this colicky abdominal pain is replaced by the dull aching constant pain and this indicates strangulation.

questions.text: A 30-years old lady presented with acute pain abdomen, constipation and vomiting suspecting acute intestinal obstruction. The investigation of choice for the patient is: (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) For a 30-year-old lady presenting with acute pain abdomen, constipation, and vomiting, strongly suspecting acute intestinal obstruction, the X-ray abdomen (typically including erect and supine postures) is considered the initial investigation of choice. This is due to its widespread availability, low cost, and ability to rapidly confirm the presence of intestinal obstruction by revealing characteristic findings such as dilated bowel loops and multiple air-fluid levels (especially visible on the erect film). These findings are crucial for a presumptive diagnosis of obstruction, allowing for prompt initiation of management, such as fluid resuscitation, nasogastric tube decompression, and surgical consultation. Why other options are incorrect or less preferred as the initial investigation of choice: B. Barium enema: This involves administering barium contrast rectally to visualize the large bowel. It is generally contraindicated or used with extreme caution in suspected acute intestinal obstruction, especially if there's a risk of bowel perforation or if the obstruction is in the small bowel. Introducing contrast can worsen the obstruction or lead to severe peritonitis if leakage occurs. Therefore, it is not an appropriate initial investigation in this acute setting. C. USG (Ultrasonography): While USG is non-invasive and doesn't involve radiation, its utility in diagnosing intestinal obstruction is limited compared to X-ray or CT. Bowel gas often obscures visualization, making it difficult to assess the entire length of the bowel and pinpoint the exact site or cause of obstruction accurately. While it might show dilated loops or free fluid, it lacks the comprehensive detail needed for definitive diagnosis and management planning in obstruction. D. CT scan: A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is indeed the most accurate and comprehensive imaging modality for diagnosing, characterizing, and identifying the cause and complications of intestinal obstruction. It can provide detailed information crucial for guiding definitive management. However, in many clinical algorithms and for the initial rapid assessment in an emergency setting, plain X-rays are often performed first. The question asks for the "investigation of choice," which, especially in the context of older AIIMS questions, often refers to the initial, rapid diagnostic tool before more advanced imaging (like CT) is performed for detailed characterization. In many emergency departments, a plain X-ray is the very first imaging step after clinical evaluation for suspected obstruction.

questions.text: A women of 35-years, comes to emergency department with symptoms of pain in abdomen and bilious vomiting but no distension of bowel. Abdominal X-ray showed no air fluid level. Diagnosis is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) in duodenal obstruction there is no dilated segment distal to this part so is does not present as dilated bowel loops and do not have multiple air fluid levels but as the obstruction is in the duodenum it presents as bilious vomiting. Option A is wrong as if the cause of intestinal obstruction was rectal carcinoma then dilated bowel loops would have occurred first and vomiting would have been a late feature of intestinal obstruction in this scenario. Option C and D that is adynamic ileus and pseudo obstruction also have distended large bowel and some air fluid levels but vomiting is a late feature.

choices.text: Atresia of the 3rd part of the duodenum

questions.text: One of the following will always present with bilious vomiting: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) atresia of 3rd part of duodenum always presents as a bilious vomiting. As bile duct opens in the second part of duodenum and as the obstruction is just distal to it, it presents as bilious vomiting. Option A and B that is pyloric stenosis and Esophageal atresia never present as bilious vomiting as obstruction is proximal to the opening of bile duct in the intestine. Option D that is malrotation of gut may or may not present as bilious vomiting.

questions.text: Distended abdomen in intestinal obstruction is mainly due to: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cause of intestinal distension

questions.text: In case of new born, the commonest cause of intestinal obstruction is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) MC site of intestinal atresia: Duodenum MC cause of neonatal intestinal obstruction: Duodenal atresia

choices.text: Operate after minimum 10 days of conservative treatment

questions.text: Regarding adhesive intestinal obstruction, true is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) TREATMENT OF ADHESIVE OBSTRUCTION • Initial management is based on intravenous rehydration and nasogastric decompression; occasionally, this treatment is curative. • Although an initial conservative regimen is considered appropriate, regular assessment is mandatory to ensure that strangulation does not occur. • Conservative treatment should not be prolonged beyond 72 hours. • When, as is usual, laparotomy is required, although multiple adhesions may be found, one may be causative. This should be divided and the remaining adhesions left in situ unless severe angulation is present. Division of these adhesions will only cause further adhesion formation. • When obstruction is caused by an area of multiple adhesions, the adhesions should be freed by sharp dissection. • To prevent recurrence, the bare area should be covered with omental grafts. • Laparoscopic adhesiolysis may be considered in highly selected cases of chronic subacute obstruction.

questions.text: The first to appear in a case of acute intestinal obstruction is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pain in Intestinal Obstruction • It is colicky in nature and is usually centred on the umbilicus (small bowel) or lower abdomen (large bowel). • The pain coincides with increased peristaltic activity. • With increasing distension, the colicky pain is replaced by a mild constant diffuse pain. • The development of severe pain is indicative of the presence of strangulation. • Pain may not be a signifcant feature in postoperative simple mechanical obstruction and does not usually occur in paralytic ileus.

choices.text: Multiple air gas shadows on X-ray

questions.text: Best way to diagnose lower small intestinal obstruction: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) X-ray is the primary investigation but CECT is IOC to diagnose intestinal obstruction Option A is not the answer as pain abdomen is a nonspecific symptom which is colicky to begin with in intestinal obstruction but is not the best way to make the diagnosis of intestinal obstruction. Option B that is abdominal distension does occur in intestinal obstruction but it is a late feature of intestinal obstruction and thus can not be taken as a feature to make the diagnosis of intestinal obstruction. Option C is a definitive feature of intestinal obstruction, but can not be used on its own to make the diagnosis of intestinal obstruction as this occurs in many conditions.

choices.text: Resection with end to end anastomosis
Resection with side to side anastomosis
Enterotomy, removal of worms and primary closure

questions.text: Ileal obstruction due to round worm obstruction treatment is: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intestinal luminal obstruction such as due to Bezoars or fecoliths or worm intestations are dealt with by enterotomy and removal followed by primary closure.

questions.text: A neonate presents with colicky pain and vomiting with sausage-shaped lump in the abdomen, diagnosis is: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This question shows a typical case scenario comprising of a neonate who has presented with colicky abdominal pain and vomiting with sausage shaped lump in the abdomen. This case scenario is diagnostic of intussusception. Option A is not the answer because enterocolitis tends to present with diarrhoea and abdominal pain. Option B is not the answer as if the patient would have perforation of the abdomen he would have come to you with distended abdomen rather than sausage shaped lump. Option D is not the answer as appendicitis typically presents as a pain in right iliac fossa.

choices.text: Idiopathic and more enteric rather than colonic
Lead point present in majority of cases
Resection of bowel is adequate for large bowel intussusception
Hydrostatic reduction with barium or air are done if bowel is not gangrenous.

questions.text: All statement about adult intussusception are true except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is wrong as most of the intussusceptions in adults have some or the other pathological lead point and they tend to be more colonic rather than ileal. Option B is correct as intussusception in adults tends to have a lead point. Option C is correct if there is some pathology or bowel has undergone some ischemic changes we need to subject the bowel to resection. Option D is correct as hydrostatic reduction using barium and air is the preferred treatment option if the bowel is not gangrenous.

questions.text: Intussusception usually begins from: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Intussusception is more common in children and the most common type of intussusuception is ileocolic. Colocolic intussusceptions tends to occur more commonly in elderly patients.

questions.text: A child was operated for small intestine mass with intussusception and after the operation the tumor was diagnosed in histological section. Which is the most likely tumor associated? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This question talks about a child who was operated for intussusception and was diagnosed intraoperatively as having a mass. It will most probably be a lymphoma as it will manifest as enlarged lymph nodes in the bowel wall which can serve as a lead point for the formation of intussusception Option A is carcinoid which manifests as a systemic alterations and less likely to present as an intussusception. Option B and D can give rise to intussusception but are not common in children.

choices.text: The process of reducing the intussusception

questions.text: What is intussuscipiens? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) outer layer is Intussuscipiens is the receptive part of the bowel which receives the intestinal segment in the process of intussusception. Option A is wrong and we do not have a name for the entire complex of intussusception. Option B is wrong as the name given for the entering layer in intussusception is called Intussusceptum. Option D is wrong as the process of reducing the intussuception is called milking the bowel segment which has undergone intussusception.

questions.text: A 10-months old infant presents with acute intestinal obstruction. Contrast enema X-ray shows the intussusception. Likely cause is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Peyer`s patch hypertrophy is the most common cause of intussusception in a 10 month old child. Meckel’s diverticulum, mucosal polyp and duplication cyst can also be the cause for intussusception but these causes are not common in children, they are more common in adults.

questions.text: Features of intussusception are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B,D,E) Option B is target sign which is seen in intussusception in USG examination when the bowel is seen in longitudinal section and we get this appearance because of bowel in bowel appearance. Option D is coiled spring sign and we get this in patients of intussusception when they are subjected to barium examination. Option E is Dance sign and is a clinical examination finding which we get in intussusception which basically denotes empty right iliac fossa.

questions.text: Recurrent obstruction, mass per rectum and diarrhea in child: (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rectal prolapse.The combination of recurrent obstruction, a mass per rectum, and diarrhea in a child is most characteristic of rectal prolapse. While intussusception can present with some of these symptoms, it is less likely to be a cause of recurrent obstruction and a palpable mass in the rectum, and is more commonly associated with constipation and "currant jelly" stools.

questions.text: Intussusception is frequently associated with: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Intra mural lipomas can be a cause of intussusception although rare as it serves as a lead point for the initiation of intussusception. Submucosal lipoma is the most common cause among the options mentioned which can lead to formation of intussusception.

questions.text: Henoch-Schönlein purpura may rarely cause: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) One of the features of Henoch-schonlein purpura is submucosal hemorrhages which can serve as lead point for formation of intussusception and thus henoch-schonlein purpura can lead to intussusception. Volvulus, Atrial fibrillation and hernia do not occur because of henoch-schonlein purpura .

questions.text: Claw sign seen in: (PGI Nov 15)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Claw sign is seen on barium enema and is a feature of intussusception . In volvulus we do not get claw sign, in volvulus we can have a coffee bean appearance on plain X-ray.

choices.text: Free passage of barium in the terminal ileum
Passage of feces and flatus along with barium

questions.text: Complete treatment of intussusception is indicated by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In cases of intussusception barium enema acts as a diagnostic as well as a therapeutic modality. With the help of barium enema sometimes intussusception can be reduced and if we notice free passing of barium into terminal ileum it is an indicator of successful treatment of intussusception.

questions.text: Post-operative ileus is most pronounced in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) After any intrabdominal surgery sequence in which patient regains peristalsis is small intestine, stomach and then large intestine. As large intestine is the last to regain the peristalsis, post operative ileus is most pronounced in colon.

questions.text: First to recover from post-operative ileus: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Part of bowel which is first to regain the motility after operation is small intestine, then stomach and the part of bowel which is last to regain the motility is large intestine.

questions.text: Routine management of paralytic ileus includes all of the following except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mainstay of the treatment in paralytic ileus is nasogastric aspiration and iv fluids. If there is any underlying electrolyte abnormality it should be corrected. We do not use parasympathomimetics as a part of treatment protocol in paralytic ileus. It is used for colonic pseudoobstruction.

choices.text: Intestinal peristalsis never becomes normal again

questions.text: True about postoperative ileus is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) POI may be generally defined as a transient impairment in gastrointestinal (GI) motility in the postoperative setting; Postoperative hypomotility may affect all parts of the GI tract but with differential recovery of normal function.due to hypomotility,no intestinal sounds are heard. Small intestine function generally normalizes first, often within several hours of surgery. Gastric motility usually returns to normal within 24-48 hours after surgery. The colon is usually the final portion of the GI tract to regain normal motility, which usually occurs within 48-72 hours after surgery. Motility normalizes in the proximal colon first and then progresses to the transverse and left colon. Most data support that colonic dysfunction is most frequently the factor that limits resolution of postoperative ileus.

questions.text: All are true statement about Meckel's diverticulum except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Diarrhea is not a common fining which we see in meckel’s diverticulum. Option A is correct as meckel’s diverticulum follows rule of 2 and it occurs in 2% of population. Option B is correct as perforation is one of the complications of meckel’s diverticulum. Option C is correct as meckel’s diverticulum occurs on antimesenteric border only. Option D is correct as ectopic gastric tissue is a common feature which is found in the meckel’s diverticulum.

questions.text: Ectopic mucosa of Meckel's diverticulum is diagnosed by: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in the diverticulum so this is used to diagnose meckel’s diverticulum with good sensitivity. Option B, C and D can be used but are not better than Tc 99 radionuclide scan.

choices.text: All incidentally detected Meckel's diverticulum should be resected.

questions.text: All are true about Meckel's diverticulum except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) all incidentally detected Meckel’s diverticulum should not be resected as the those which have wide mouth and no ectopic gastric tissue can be left alone. Option A is correct as meckel’s diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum as it is present since birth. Option B is correct as meckel’s is a true diverticulum as it contains all the three layers in it. Option C is correct as meckel’s diverticulum is a remnant of omphalomesenteric duct which is also called as vitello intestinal duct.

questions.text: Most common presenting complication of Meckel's diverticulum: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • MC complication in children and young adults and overall: Bleeding • MC complication in adults: Intestinal obstruction Intussusception, diverticulitis and obstruction are all the complications of meckel’s diverticulum but the most common complication is haemorrhage.

questions.text: Meckel's diverticulum is a derivative of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Meckel’s diverticulum of vitellointestinal duct, it is also called as omphalomesenteric duct and usually obliterates as the child grows but if it fails to obliterate or obliterate partially then it presents as a meckel’s diverticulum.

questions.text: The most frequent congenital anomaly of the GI tract is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most frequent congenital anomaly of GI tract is Meckel’s Diverticulum and is present in 2 % of population.

choices.text: Located 60 cm from the caecal valve

questions.text: All of the following are true about Meckel's diverticulum except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Meckel’s diverticulum occurs on the antimesenteric border and not the mesenteric border. Option A and B is correct as bleeding and intussusception are are the complications of Meckel’s Diverticulum. Option D is correct as Meckel’s diverticulum follows the rule of 2 and is situated 2 feet that is 60 cm proximal to ileocaecal junction.

choices.text: Is found on the anti-mesenteric border of the small intestine.
Consists of mucosa without a muscle coat.
Heterotopic gastric mucosa can ulcerate and cause a brisk gastrointestinal bleed.
A fibrous band between the apex and umbilicus can cause intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is incorrect regarding Meckel's diverticulum? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is wrong as meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum and consists of all the three layers that is mucosa muscle coat and serosa. Option A is correct as meckel’s diverticulum is present always on the antimesenteric border of the intestine. Option C is correct as ectopic gastric mucosa can be present in the meckel’s diverticulum and due to the acid production by the gastric mucosa there can occur ulceration of the mucosa and this can lead to bleeding. Option D is correct as sometimes there occurs a fibrous band between the meckels diverticulum and the umbilicus and intestine can roll around this fibrous band and lead to intestinal obstruction.

choices.text: Can be a leading point of intussusception

questions.text: True about Meckel's diverticulum is/are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A & B) Option A is the answer as Meckel’s diverticulum when associated with gastric mucosa is notorious of causing bleeding which can present as bleeding PR. Option B is correct as meckel’s diverticulum can act as a lead point and lead to intussusception. Option C is wrong as meckel’s diverticulum is almost always a single diverticula arising from the antimesenteric border. Option D is wrong as Meckel’s diverticulum is visualised best on radionuclide scan rather than barium meal. Option E is wrong because when meckel’s diverticulum presents as a complication like bleeding, intestinal obstruction or a perforation we need to do an intervention in order to treat the patient.

questions.text: The commonest presentation of Meckel's diverticulum is: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) bleeding is the most common presentation of Meckel’s Diverticulum. Obstruction, Diverticulitis and intussusception are other rare presentations of meckel’s diverticulum.

choices.text: Most common congenital anomaly of small intestine
Most common is ectopic gastric mucosa
Bleeding may occur from the wall
Wide mouth stapling at the base for non bleeding cases

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true about Meckel's diverticulum? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is correct as meckel’s diverticulum is the most common congenital anomaly of the GI tract. Option B is correct as most common ectopic tissue situated in the meckel’s diverticum is gastric tissue. Option C is correct as if the gastric ectopic tissue is present in the meckel’s diverticulum, then due to acid production the mucosa adjacent to the diverticulum can ulcerate and lead to bleeding. Option D is wrong as we do not go for stapling at the base for wide mouth meckel’s which are not bleeding, we just leave them alone.

questions.text: Uncommon complication of Meckel's diverticulum: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is the answer to this question as malignancy is the least common complication of meckel’s diverticulum. Option D that is bleeding is the most common complication of meckel’s diverticulum. Option A that is intussusception and Diverticulitis are not as common as bleeding or obstruction but can still occur.

questions.text: Efficacy of Tc-Pertechnetate scan is increased by all except: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Any factor that slows the GI motility increases the sensitivity of the Tc-pertechnate scan. Option D that is metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent and thus increases the GI motility and reduces the sensitivity of the Tc-pertechnate scan.

questions.text: Acquired diverticula are most commonly in seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A diverticulum is an abnormal sac or pouch protruding from the wall of a hollow organ • True diverticulum is composed of all layers of the intestinal wall • False diverticulum (pseudodiverticulum) lacks a portion of the normal bowel wall. • Acquired diverticula are the MC type and are mainly false diverticula • MC site of colonic diverticula and diverticula overall is Sigmoid colon

questions.text: True about diverticulitis: A. Occur at any age B. Often incidental finding at operation C. Young patient has more aggressive disease D. Left sided colon involvement is more common E. Operation is not done for all patients
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (D & E) Option A is false as diverticulitis is more common in adults and virtually non existent in children. Option B is false as diverticulitis is never asymptomatic it is always symptomatic, diverticulosis can be asymptomatic and can be incidentally detected. Option C Is false as the natural course of diverticulitis tends to be more aggressive in older individual . Option D is correct as diverticulitis is more common on left side with sigmoid colon being the most common site. Option E is also correct as we do not require operation in all the stages of diverticulitis, stages I and II can be managed conservatively or percutaneous interventions and higher stages need operative intervention.

questions.text: True regarding colovesical fistula is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) in colovescical fistula ,there is fistulous communication between colon and urinary bladder so they present as pneumaturia. Option B is false barium enema can be done but is not diagnostic. We need to do a CT and MRI to make the proper diagnosis and know the extent of colovesical fistula. Option C is false as colovesical fistula is more common in males as compared to females. Option D is wrong as most of the cases of colovescical fistula in diverticulitis is caused by the disease process itself and not by any surgical intervention.

questions.text: Most common fistula in diverticulitis of colon"
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) most common fistula in diverticulitis is colovesical.

questions.text: Colonic diverticulosis is best diagnosed by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Investigation of choice for colonic diverticulosis: Barium enema Investigation of choice for diverticulitis: CT scan

questions.text: Massive colonic bleeding in a patient of diverticulosis is from: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Although diverticular disease is much more common on the left side, right-sided disease is responsible for more than half episodes of bleeding (from SMA).

choices.text: Sigmoidoscope cannot be passed beyond 15 cm

questions.text: In acute diverticulitis of the colon, the sigmoidoscopic finding is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer to this question as in patients with diverticulitis on sigmoidoscopy we see inflamed mucosa . Option B is is not correct as on sigmoidoscopy we can not comment on the size of the diverticula we need CT scan for this. Option C is wrong as saw tooth appearance is seen In diverticulosis but on barium enema. Option D is false as sigmoidoscope can be passed upto 30-40 cm in length.

questions.text: Diverticular disease is not common in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Incidence of diverticula: Colon >Meckel’s >Duodenum >Pharynx >Esophagus >Stomach >Jejunum >Appendix >Ileum.

choices.text: Conservative treatment may be successful in severe attack

questions.text: Which of the following about acute diverticulitis is incorrect? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In Diverticulitis fistula arising from the colon is rarely a cause for emergency surgery; infact, the patient general condition is often improved when the abscess fistulizes and drains. Antibiotics should be administered to reduce the adjacent cellulitis, and the diagnostic steps should be taken to confirm the cause of the fistula before a definitive operation is undertaken Option A is correct as Sigmoid colon is the most common site for diverticulitis Option B is correct as peri-colic abscess can occur after diverticulitis.

questions.text: A obese old patient with diverticular disease if presents with perforation, what will the treatment of choice? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In an emergency condition presenting with perforation in diverticulitis ,Hartmann’s operation is the most common technique for emergency operations required for control of infection secondary to diverticulitis, In this case we do not perform immediate anastomosis between descending colon and rectum as there is high chance that it will leak and complicate because of excessive inflammed and edematous tissue. Anastomosis between the descending colon and rectum to restore intestinal continuity is done after a period of at least 10 weeks.

choices.text: Rigid sigmoidoscopy is the initial treatment

questions.text: Sigmoid volvulus: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rigid sigmoidoscopy is the treatment done for sigmoid volvulus as some of the patients are treated by this intervention as a rigid sigmoidoscope helps in derotation of the bowel which has undergone a anticlockwise rotation. Option A is not the answer as in most of the patients of sigmoid volvulus we have a anticlockwise rotation of sigmoid. Option B is wrong as CECT is diagnostic for sigmoid volvulus but It can be diagnosed on X ray abdomen standing and Barium enema.therefore we dont usually order a CT. Option D is wrong as sigmoidectomy is not contraindicated in sigmoid volvulus, if on exploration we see a gangrenous or ischemic sigmoid colon we have to undertake a sigmoidectomy operation for the treatment.

choices.text: In absence of ischemia, mesocolopexy is done
Ogilvie's syndrome refers to cecal volvulus

questions.text: False about volvulus: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ogilvie’s syndrome is another name of colonic pseudoobstruction. It does not indicate a volvulus. Option A is correct as sigmoid volvulus Is the most common type of large intestinal volvulus. Option B is correct as if there is no ischemia then we have to do meocolopexy for the treatment after the normal position of sigmoid colon is stablished. Option D is correct if there is excessive dilation of the bowel segment we have to undertake elective sigmoid resection.

choices.text: Resolves with endoscopic treatment as frequently as sigmoid volvulus
Right hemicolectomy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: In cecal volvulus: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is the answer as right hemicolectomy is the treatment of choice in cecal volvulus. Option A is wrong as cecal volvulus does not resolve with endoscopic treatment as frequently as sigmoid volvulus. Option C is false as cecal volvulus is not treated by conservative management, we need to do surgical intervention for its treatment. Option D is false as colonoscopic decompression is not a very effective treatment option for cecal volvulus.

questions.text: Obstruction with multiple air fluid levels in a newborn, suggest diagnosis of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Midgut volvulus is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in a new born child. If it is present it will manifest as a multiple airfluid levels on plain X-ray abdomen standing. Option A is false as duodenal atresia will present as a double bubble appearance on plain X-ray. Option B is false as ileal atresia will present as a triple bubble appearance on plain X-ray. Option C is ladd’s band, persistence of ladd’s band does not indicate obstruction. It predisposes a patient to develop midgut volvulus due to narrow mesentery.

questions.text: 'Bird of prey' sign is seen in the radiographic barium examination of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Barium enema is helpful for making the diagnosis of sigmoid volvulus , on barium enema we see birds beak appearance, ace of spade sign or Bird of prey sign. Option B is wrong as in intussusception on barium study we see claw sign or coils of spring appearance. Option C is wrong as in caecal volvulus we see kidney bean appearance or a comma shaped caecum.

questions.text: False about cecal volvulus: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is false as most of cecal volvulus patients are not treated by colonoscopic reduction . Most of sigmoid volvulus can be treated with rigid sigmoidoscopy which acts like therapeutic option. Option B is correct as cecal volvulus is more common than caecal buscule which denotes a condition where there is anterior cephalad turnover of caecum over ascending colon. Option C Is correct as the treatment of choice for this condition is right hemicolectomy. Option D is correct as actually cecal volvulus is cecocolic volvulus.

questions.text: Coffee bean sign is usually seen in: (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Coffee bean appearance is seen on plain X ray abdomen in case of sigmoid volvulus.It is also referred to as bent inner tube appearance or omega sign. Option B is wrong as in pyloric stenosis we get double duct or rail road track sign on barium meal, most of the cases are diagnosed on USG without the need of any barium investigation. Option C is wrong as in intussusception we get a target sign or a claw sign on barium. Option D is wrong as we get multiple air fluid levels on X-ray abdomen standing.

questions.text: Rotation of sigmoid volvulus occurs: (PGI Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) most of the cases of sigmoid volvulus occur due to anticlockwise rotation. But in sigmoid volvulus rotation can occur in clockwise direction also.

questions.text: All are predisposing factors for sigmoid volvulus except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) tuberculosis does not predisposes the patient to sigmoid volvulus. Options A,B and C i.e. Hirschsprung’s disease, Chagas disease and Chronic constipation are the predisposing factors for sigmoid volvulus.

questions.text: According to Hagitt's classification, a polyp invading neck in between head and stalk is level: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Intestinal polyps that can potentially grow into cancer
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer to this question as adenomatous polyps tend to grow into cancer. Option B that is hyperplastic polyps are most common type of colorectal polyps and are non neoplastic. Option C that is juvenile polyp is also a type of non neoplastic polyp. Option D that is hamartomatous polyp are another type of non neoplastic polyp.

choices.text: Fibrocystic disease of breast and breast cancer

questions.text: Cowden's disease is characterized by the following except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is the answer in this question as in cowden’s disease we get multiple hamartomatous polyps which do not predispose to colorectal malignancy. Option A is correct as in cowden syndrome there is predilection for fibrocystic disease of breast and breast malignancy. Option B that is facial trichilemmomas are a feature of cowden syndrome. Option D that is Acral keratosis is also a feature of cowden’s disease . Cowden syndrome occurs because of PTEN gene mutation on chromosome 10. Autosomal dominant in nature.

questions.text: All are true about risk factor for malignancy in polyp except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) pedunculated polyp is not a risk factor for malignancy.Sessile polyps are a risk factor. Option B is correct as If the polyp is >2cm then this predisposes to colorectal malignancy. Option C that is Villous polyp is a type of adenomatous polyp which has a maximum malignant potential. Option D that is Cellular atypia is again a feature of malignancy.

questions.text: Carcinoma of the colon develops in all patients with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Familial adenomatous polyposis is a condition caused by APC gene mutation on chromosome 5q21 and this condition is associated with 100 % risk of malignancy if left untreated. Juvenile polyp, hamartomatous polyp and inflammatory polyp are non neoplastic polyps and are not associated with the risk of malignancy.

questions.text: Diagnosis of colonic polyps is best done radiologically using: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Best investigation for diagnosis of colorectal polyps: Colonoscopy >Double-contrast barium enema Double contrast barium enema showing colorectal polyp.

questions.text: Which polyp has maximum malignant potential? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) maximum risk of colorectal polyp is associated with sessile polyp. Option B that is pedunculated polyps are not associated with risk of malignancy.

questions.text: Incidence of malignancy is maximum in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer to this question as villous adenoma is a type of adenomatous polyp which has maximum risk of colorectal malignancy. Option B that is juvenile polyp is a type of non neoplastic colorectal polyp. Option C that is hyperplastic polyp is another type of non neoplastic colorectal polyp. Option D that is tubular adenoma is a type of adenomatous polyp. Infact it is the most common type of adenomatous polyp and has malignant potential but the malignant potential is less than villous polyp.

choices.text: Polyps of the familial polyposis coli could invariably undergo malignant change
Pseudopolyps of ulcerative colitis has high risk of malignancy
Villous adenoma is associated with high risk of malignancy
Juvenile polyps have little or no risk

questions.text: All the following statements regarding malignant potential of colorectal polyps are true except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is the answer in this case as pseudopolyps of ulcerative colitis are not associated with any malignant potential. Ulcerative colitis per se has malignant potential but the inflammatory polyps have no malignant potential. Option A is correct as polyps of familial polyposis coli can undergo malignant transformation. Option C is correct as villous adenoma is a type of adenomatous polyp and has a maximum risk of malignant transformation. Option D is correct as juvenile polyps are a type of non neoplastic polyps with no risk of malignant transformation.

questions.text: Which of the following polyps is not premalignant?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B, C & E) Option A is juvenile polyposis syndrome and it is a non neoplastic polyp. Option B that is peutz- jegher’s polyp is also a non neoplastic polyp. Option C that is pseudopolyps of ulcerative colitis not a pre malignant condition. Ulcerative colitis is a premalignant condition. Option D that is familial adenomatous coli or Familial adenomatous polyposis is a condition caused by APC gene mutation and carries a 100 % risk of malignancy if left untreated. Option E that is cronkhite Canada syndrome is an acquired, nonhereditary, non-familial gastrointestinal polyposis disorder associated with skin pigmentary changes, hair loss, and nail atrophy (onychodystrophy) which has no evidence of colorectal malignancy.

questions.text: All of the following are pre-malignant except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is the answer to this question as Peutz- Jegher’s syndrome is not associated with colorectal malignancies. Option A and B that is Crohn’s disease and Ulcerative colitis predispose to colorectal malignancy, out of these two ulcerative colitis has a more risk as compared to crohn’s disease . Option D that is barrett’s oesophagus is also a risk factor for malignancy.

questions.text: Metabolic abnormality seen in large colorectal villous adenoma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) MCKITTRICK-WHEELOCK SYNDROME • Villous adenoma causing profuse watery diarrhea and hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypochloremia and metabolic acidosis. • Severe volume loss can lead to acute renal failure and cardiovascular collapse. • Treatment is resuscitation followed by resection.

questions.text: Lalita, a female patient presents with pigmentation of the lips and oral mucosa and intestinal polyps. Her sister also gives the same history. Most probable diagnosis is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is the answer in this question as Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome consists of hamartomatous polyps (usually <100) throughout the GIT, most common in jejunum. Associated with hypermelanotic macule in the perioral region, buccal mucosa. Mucocutaneous pigmentation usually occurs during infancy and most commonly noted in perioral and buccal region. Option A that is carcinoid syndrome presents with symptoms like flushing and other features of serotonin excess. Option B that is melanoma is a neoplastic lesion and kindly note that hyper pigmentated lesions of peutz jeghers syndrome are not premalignant.

questions.text: Strong correlation with colorectal cancer is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Familal polyposis coli is a condition which predisposes to colorectal malignancies. Peutz-jegher’s polyp, juvenile polyposis and hyperplastic polyp are benign polyps and do not predispose to colorectal cancer.

questions.text: Prophylactic polypectomy is done is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is the answer in this question as we never do prophylactic polypectomy in multiple polyposis syndromes. If the patient is suffering from Familial adenomatous polyposis we go for prophylactic total colectomy . And if the polyps are leading to recurrent intussuception we just resect that particular polyp which is acting like a lead point.

choices.text: Epidermal cysts and osteomas may occur

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about FAP? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Familial Adenomatous Polyposis is an autosomal dominant condition caused by APC gene mutation on chromosome 5q . Option B is correct as in patients suffering from FAP we do screening with sigmoidoscopy and colonoscopy and this screening starts at the age of 20. Option C is correct as in FAP polyps develop at around 20-30 years and 100 % of patients develop malignancy by the age of 40 years . Option D is correct as epidermoid cyst and osteomas can be associated with FAP and this is called as Gardner’s Syndrome.

questions.text: Recommended treatment of FAP involving sigmoid colon: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In patients with FAP syndrome there is 100% risk of development of malignancy if it is left untreated. So in FAP involving sigmoid colon treatment option is total proctocolectomy with IPAA.

choices.text: Endometrial carcinoma is a prominent association

questions.text: Are true about FAP except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is the answer to this question as Endometrial carcinoma is a prominent association of HNPCC and not FAP. Option A is correct as in FAP we need >100 polyps to make the diagnosis . Option B is correct as in FAP we have mutation in APC gene located on chromosome 5q Option C is correct as Sulindac has been used because of its potential to stabilize, and in some cases reverse, the development of gastrointestinal neoplasia, especially colorectal adenomas.Budesonide is also protective.

questions.text: Most common associated cancer in FAP: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2nd most common cancer in FAP is periampullary CA.

choices.text: In stomach, most common are gastric adenomas

questions.text: Which of the following is not about FAP? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Incidence of duodenal polyps in the patients with FAP: 90-100% Incidence of duodenal carcinoma in the patients with FAP: 0-5%

questions.text: Gardner's syndrome is associated with all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gardner’s Syndrome is the combination of FAP with: • Bony lesions (osteomas, cortical thickening of long bones and ribs) • Benign lymphoid polyposis of ileum • Dental anomalies (impacted tooth, supernumerary tooth, dental cyst) • Desmoid tumors and sebaceous cyst.

questions.text: Turcot's syndrome is associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B & C) TURCOT’S SYNDROME (AR) • MC brain tumors are medulloblastoma and glioblastoma. • It is a phenotypic variant of FAP and is transmitted by an autosomal recessive gene.

questions.text: The most common facial abnormality in Gardener's syndrome: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) GARDNER’S SYNDROME (AD) • Skeletal abnormalities, the most common of which are osteomas, are an essential component of Gardner syndrome. • The osteomas are characterized by slow, continuous growth, and occur most frequently in the mandible, the outer cortex of the skull and the paranasal sinuses. • The angle of the mandible is a particularly diagnostic site.

questions.text: Following genetic counselling in a family for Familial polyposis coli, next screening test is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Most common method used to screen for FAP is the APC gene testing by protein truncation test. If APC gene is mutated : Screening starts at 10 years of age ( Sigmoidoscopy is done annually) If polyps are seen : Surgery If no polyPs till 18 years of age :-Risk of cancer is same as general population.

questions.text: Premalignant conditions is/are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A & C) Risk Factors for the Development of Colorectal Cancer 1. Dietary Factors: High animal fat diet ,Low fiber diet ,Alcohol 2. Hereditary syndromes: FAP , HNPCC 3. Infammatory bowel disease (Both UC and Crohn’s disease) 4. Streptococcus bovis bacteremia 5. Ureterosigmoidostomy 6. Smoking 7. Acromegaly 8. Pelvic irradiation

questions.text: Based on epidemiological studies, which of the following has been found to be most protective against carcinoma colon? (LQ
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) High fiber diet has been found to have protective effect by increasing the stool bulk, diluting the toxins, and reducing the colonic transit time and thus reducing exposure time to faecal carcinogens.

questions.text: Genetic abnormality in case of late adenoma to carcinoma in CA colon: (AIIMS NOV 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The most frequently mutated tumor suppressor gene in human neoplasia is p53 (TP53), located on chromosome 17p. Mutations in p53 are present in 75% of colorectal cancers and occur, rather late in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence.

questions.text: All of the following genes may be involved in development of carcinoma of colon except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Cholecystectomy may lead to increased risk of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer in this question as bile acids can induce hyperproliferation of the intestinal mucosa via a number of intracellular mechanisms. Cholecystectomy, which alters the enterohepatic cycle of bile acids, has been associated with a moderately increased risk of proximal colon cancers. Cholecystectomy per se do not increase the risk of pancreatic, hepatic Ca or cholangiocarcinoma.

choices.text: Japanese are common to develop carcinoma colon

questions.text: Dietary factors associated with colon carcinoma:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B, D & E) Option A is wrong as high fibre diet infact reduces the risk of colorectal cancer . Option B is correct as the diet which is low in fiber content increases the risk of colorectal cancer . Option C is wrong as smoked fish do not increases the risk of colorectal cancer. Option D is correct as the diet which has high fat content has increased risk of developing colorectal cancer. Option E is also correct as colorectal cancer tends to occur more in Japanese people due to their dietary habits.

questions.text: Which among the following is not premalignant? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is the answer to this question as peutz-jegher’s syndrome is not a premalignant condition .it is a benign condition having colonic polyps. Option A is premalignant as ulcerative colitis definitely increases the risk of colorectal malignancy and the risk increases depending on the duration of the disease . Option C that is villous adenoma is the most malignant of all the adenomatous polyps. Option D that is familial adenomatous polyposis is a condition caused by the mutation in APC gene and predisposes to colorectal malignancy.

questions.text: Most common site of colonic carcinoma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) most common site of colorectal malignancy among the options given is sigmoid. Colorectal malignancies are more common in rectum as compared to sigmoid but as rectum is not in the option the answer is sigmoid colon.

questions.text: Constricting type of colonic carcinoma is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) carcinoma colon which tends to occur on left side are constricting type and thus lead to obstruction due to stricture formation. Option B that is right colon carcinoma colon which tends to occur on the right side are fungating and tend to present with occult bleeding. Option C that is transverse colon, the carcinoma which arise in this region can be either fungating or constricting so it can present as bleeding or as obstruction.

questions.text: Ramu is 60 years old male with CA descending colon presents with acute intestinal obstruction. In emergency department treatment of choice is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is the answer in this question as hartman’s procedure is a proctosigmoidectomy, procedure is the surgical resection of the rectosigmoid colon with closure of the anorectal stump and formation of an end colostomy. It was used to treat colon cancer or inflammation (proctosigmoiditis, proctitis, diverticulitis, etc.). Currently, its use is limited to emergency surgery when immediate anastomosis is not possible, or more rarely it is used palliatively in patients with colorectal tumours Option A is wrong as the stoma which is made in colorectal carcinoma is a diversion colostomy and not the defunctioning colostomy. Option C and D that is total colectomy or hemicolectomy are the procedures which are rarely done in emergency setting.

questions.text: Carcinoma of right colon presents as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A & B) Option A is the answer to this question as right sided colonic carcinomas tend to be fungating and thus present as chronic bleeding which manifests as anaemia. Option B is also correct as in cases where the carcinoma is involving caecum or ascending colon the tumour may increase in size and present as mass in right iliac fossa or a lump in the abdomen. Option C is wrong as patients do not come as bleeding PR rather patient has chronic blood loss which presents as occult blood loss. Option D is wrong as left sided colonic cancers tend to present as obstruction and constipation not the right sided colonic malignancies.

questions.text: Features of left side carcinoma colon are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B & C) Option A is wrong as right sided colonic cancer teds to present as anaemia not the left sided colonic cancer. Option B is correct as left sided colonic cancer tends to present as colonic strictures and so they are the ones which tend to present as intestinal obstruction . Option C is also correct as left sided colonic cancers are the ones which present as altered bowel habit due to stricture formation so they present as diarrhea and constipation alternately. Option E is wrong as proximal or right sided colonic cancers may present as feculent vomiting rather than left sided colonic cancers.

choices.text: Lesion on left side of the colon presents with features of anemia
Mucinous carcinoma has a good prognosis
Duke's A stage should receive adjuvant chemotherapy
Solitary liver metastasis is not a contraindication for surgery

questions.text: True regarding carcinoma colon is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) solitary liver metastasis is not a contraindication for surgery. Infact in colorectal malignancies if there is liver or pulmonary metastasis we can resect it and it is not a contraindication for the surgery. Contraindications to resection of liver metastasis are as follows: The presence of four metastasis or more Extrahepatic disease A resection margin of <1 cm. Option A is wrong as lesions of left side of colon do not present as anaemia they present as obstruction. Lesions of right side of colon present as anaemia. Option B is false as mucinous carcinoma has a poor prognosis.

choices.text: Have better image than conventional colonoscopy
VC is performed by CT and MRI
Take more time than conventional colonoscopy

questions.text: True about virtual colonoscopy:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B & E) VC is a medical imaging procedure which uses x-rays and computers to produce two-and three-dimensional images of the colon and rectum and display them on a screen Option A is correct as virtual colonoscopy is the radiological 3D reconstruction of colon, it is better than conventional colonoscopy. Option B is correct as virtual colonoscopy is just the 3 D reconstruction of the image and can be performed by CT scan or MRI. Option C is wrong as it takes lesser time than conventional colonoscopy. Option D is absolutely wrong as we have seen that virtual colonoscopy is the 3D reconstruction of the images we can not take a biopsy of tissue as this is a non invasive radiological test. Option E is correct and this also a major advantage of performing a virtual colonoscopy that it gives us a good idea about any pathology which is present outside the lumen of colon.

questions.text: Colonic disease can be diagnosed by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C, D & E) Barium swallow is used for anatomical disorders of esophagus. Barium meal is used for anatomical disorders of stomach. Barium meal follow through is used for anatomical disorders of small intestine Barium enema is used for anatomical disorders of large intestine Enteroclysis is also known as small bowel enema, used for small intestine.

questions.text: colonic metastases are related with: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is the answer to this question as Incidence of metastasis (hence prognosis) is related to depth of invasion. Option A is wrong as preop CEA do not correlate with metastasis, they just serve as a baseline tumour marker to be reviewed after cancer resection. Option C is wrong as tumour size and duration of symptoms have no effect on risk of colonic metastasis and prognosis. Tumour size and configuration (endophytic, exophytic, annular) do not carry any prognostic significance in colorectal carcinoma.

choices.text: Screening the stool for occult blood

questions.text: What is an acceptable screening technique for detecting recurrent colon cancer? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker that is commonly used for monitoring patients after treatment for colon cancer. Serial measurement of CEA levels is an accepted and widely used screening tool for detecting recurrence of colon cancer, especially in patients who have undergone curative resection. Rising CEA levels can be an early indicator of recurrence, even before clinical or radiological signs appear. Incorrect options: A. Screening sigmoidoscopy While sigmoidoscopy is a valid method for detecting initial colorectal cancer, especially in the distal colon, it is not typically used to monitor for recurrence, particularly in patients who have had a prior full evaluation and treatment for colon cancer. B. Screening the stool for occult blood Fecal occult blood testing (FOBT) is useful for initial screening in asymptomatic individuals but is not reliable for detecting recurrence in patients already treated for colon cancer. It lacks the sensitivity and specificity needed for surveillance. C. Stool cytology Stool cytology is not a recommended or reliable method for screening or monitoring colon cancer. It has low diagnostic accuracy and is rarely used in clinical practice for this purpose.

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for colorectal carcinoma is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) PROGNOSTIC FACTORS IN COLORECTAL CARCINOMA • Most important prognostic factor for colorectal carcinoma: Stage of the disease • Single most important independent prognostic factor for colorectal carcinoma: LN status • The stage of disease gives information related to depth of penetration into bowel wall and extent of regional node spread, both of which are the two most important independent prognostic factors. • No effect on Prognosis: Tumor size and duration of symptoms • Tumor size and configuration (endophytic, exophytic, annular) do not carry any prognostic significance in colorectal carcinoma.

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for colorectal carcinoma is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most important prognostic factor for colorectal carcinoma: Stage of the disease Single most important independent prognostic factor for colorectal carcinoma: LN status

questions.text: The best investigation for colorectal carcinoma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is the answer to this question as the best investigation to diagnose colorectal carcinoma is colonoscopy and biopsy.

questions.text: The commonest site of perforation during colonoscopy is: (AIIMS NOV 2013)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • MC site of bleeding after colonoscopy: Stalk after polypectomy. • MC site of perforation during colonoscopy: Sigmoid colon • Perforation can be caused by excessive air pressure, tearing of the antimesenteric border of the colon from excessive pressure on colonic loops, and at the sites of electrosurgical applications

questions.text: Management of carcinoma rectosigmoid with obstructive carcinoma in elderly frail patient:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, D & E) In emergency setting,a patient of colonic carcinoma most commonly comes as obstruction or as perforation . Our main aim in old frill patients is not the complete cure of the disease in emergency setting as they will not be able to withstand the operation but our main aim is to find a proper diversion for the stool and relieve constipation. Option B is wrong as Abdominal perineal resection is never performed in an emergency setting it is performed always as a planned procedure. Option C is also wrong as resection and primary anastomosis if done in emergency setting there is a high chance that it will leak . So obstruction in emergency setting is best managed by performing a stoma formation, Hartman’s procedure or laser recanalization which are palliative treatment options.

questions.text: Thumb printing appearance of colon on barium enema is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Thumb printing is a radiographic sign of large bowel wall thickening, usually caused by oedema, related to an infective or inflammatory process (colitis). The normal haustra become thickened at regular intervals appearing like thumbprints projecting into the aerated lumen. It is seen in ischemic colitis.

choices.text: IMA is commonly occluded in cases needing aortic surgeries
Ischemia is more common in small bowel as compared to large bowel
Most common site of post ischemic stricture is sigmoid
Transection of IMA doesn't need reimplantation if aortic surgery is attempted

questions.text: Are true about ischemic colitis except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Indeed, the IMA is frequently occluded in conditions requiring aortic surgery, and in such circumstances, transection of the IMA does not require reimplantation. However, in this situation, the left colon is dependent on collateral blood supply, and transient hypotension at the time of the vascular procedure or immediately after surgery may result in ischemic injury to the vulnerable colonic mucosa. In aortic surgeries, the IMA is assessed for backbleeding. If there is strong backbleeding (stump pressure > 40 mm Hg), the IMA is ligated close to the aorta or oversewn from within the sac. Poor backbleeding from the IMA is a sign of insufficient collateral circulation to the sigmoid colon, and reimplantation of the IMA with a patch of the aorta into the aortic limb is warranted.

questions.text: Most common site of post ischemic stricture is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) As you can clearly see in the above figure there is a watershed area at the sigmoid colon so sigmoid colon is the most frequently affected part in post ischemic stricture.

choices.text: Octreotide to decrease the bowel secretions
Reoperation to close the fistulous tract

questions.text: A 33 year old male undergoes resection with end to end anastomosis for lleal perforation. On 6th post operative day small bowel fluid starts draining through the incision with the fascia remaining intact. The fistula output is 200ml/day with no fever and no evidence of intra abdominal collection on CT scan. The MOST appropriate treatment strategy for the patient is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This is a case of low output enterocutaneous fistula without any intraabdominal collection. Most of the fistula heals spontaneously. The patient needs to be managed conservatively with TPN being the most important component of this conservative treatment.

questions.text: A 60 year old patient presents with abdominal pain and obstipation. On examination patient is afebrile , pulse rate is 94/minute and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is distended and tympanic but there are no evidence of peritoneal signs. Abdominal radiograph is suggestive of sigmoid volvulus. The first step in patients management would be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In patients of sigmoid volvulus without any signs of peritonitis, the first line of treatment in emergency is sigmoidoscopic decompression with placement of a flatus tube for 2-3 days.

Angiodysplasia is the second most common cause of Massive lower GI haemorrhage. Diverticular disease is the most common cause of Massive lower GI haemorrhage.

choices.text: Fluid resuscitation followed by endoscopic decompression is the initial preferred treatment.
Coffee bean sign seen on Plain XRAY.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ceacal volvulus is true.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Unlike sigmoid volvulus, endoscopic decompression has no role in ceacal volvulus and is usually clockwise. Coffee bean sign is seen in sigmoid volvulus. Definitive treatment of caecal volvulus is right hemicolectomy.

questions.text: A non familial GI Polyposis syndrome with presence of hamartomatus polyps with nail dystrophy, alopecia and cutaneous pigmentation is known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Crohnkite Canada syndrome is a non familial GI Polyposis syndrome associated with the above mentioned conditions while the other polyposis syndromes mentioned are inherited as a familial condition.

choices.text: Surgery followed by Chemotherapy and radiation for all patients
Surgery followed by Chemotherapy alone for all patients
Surgery followed by Chemotherapy alone for patients with high-risk histology

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Chemotherapy after surgery in colonic ca is indicated in all patients with stage III( T1-4/N1-2/M0) disease. Stage II(T3/T4 N0M0) disease:-surgery only.

choices.text: The primary fuel for colonocytes is butyric acid.
Following abdominal surgery, the colon is the last segment of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract to resume motility
Within the contiguous GI tract, the concentration of bicarbonate is highest in the colon
The colon is the site of greatest water absorption in the GI tract

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding colonic physiology are true except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Though the primary function of the colon is water absorbtion, the majority of water resorption occurs in the small bowel. Because of the electrolyte exchange that occurs with water resorption in the colon, a high concentration of bicarbonate results in the colon.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best diagnostic tool for ischemic colitis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Flexible sigmoidoscopy and colonsocopy are the diagnostic tool of choice for definitively identifying ischemic colitis. Endoscopy is highly sensitive because it allows direct visualization of the mucosa, the first layer affected by ischemia. Serial endoscopy helps in identification of worsening disease, making it possible to pursue surgical intervention before substantial clinical deterioration occurs.

choices.text: Positron emission tomography (PET) scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.text: A patient presents with osteomas of the mandible, multiple lipomas and sebaceous cysts, a history of multiple dental abnormalities,and an apparent fibrotic retroperitoneal mass on CT scan obtained for abdominal pain. The next step in management of this patient is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is a case of gardener’s syndrome which along with the extra intestinal manifestations associated with FAP. So to look for polyps and to rule out colonic ca , take a biopsy if required therefore,the next best step in the management of this patient would be a Colonoscopy.

Endoscopic excision is usually adequate treatment for level I and level II polyps
A wide-based sessile polyp with carcinoma at the tip of the polyp only is considered a level III polyp

questions.text: According to the Haggitt’s classification of colorectal polyps which of the following statements is false
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Any wide based sessile polyp with invasive ca is considered level IV.

choices.text: According to the Amsterdam criteria,diagnosis requires at least three familial generations diagnosed with colon cancer
Lynch II refers to those HNPCC patients affected by colon cancer and inflammatory bowel disease
Treatment for HNPCC includes subtotal colectomy and all female patients should be offered prophylactic hysterectomy/oopherectomy

questions.text: Which of the following statements about HNPCC is true
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Definitive treatment for HNPCC includes subtotal colectomy given the high risk of synchronous colonic tumors. Female patients are at particular risk of gynecologic malignancies and should be offered prophylactic hysterectomy and oopherectomy.

questions.text: The earliest mutation of adenoma carcinoma sequence in the development of colorectal cancer is mutation in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Earliest mutation:-The APC gene is a tumour suppressor gene located on chromosome 5q21.

Disease by itself does not cause mortality

questions.text: Which of the following features can be seen in Desmoid tumors associated with FAP following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Desmoid tumors can present in the retroperitoneum and abdominal wall of affected patients, usually after surgery. These tumors rarely metastasize but are often locally invasive; direct invasion of the mesenteric vessels, ureters, or walls of the small intestine can lead to death.

questions.text: Presently,the preferred chemotherapeutic regime for stage III colorectal cancers is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Presently the preferred regime is Oxaliplatin + 5 FU+ Leucovorin( FOLFOX) Chemotherapy regimens : FOLFOX : 5FU ,Folinic Acid , Oxaliplatin FOLFIRI : 5FU , Folinic Acid , Irinotecan CAPEOC : Capecitabine , Oxaliplatin

questions.text: For screening the family members of patients with FAP ,colonoscopy is started at the age of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The screening starts with the identification of inheritance of mutated APC at around 10-12 years of age. If identified annual flexible sigmoidoscopy / colonoscopy starts at around this age. If analysis demonstrates non inheritance of mutated APC gene, annual endoscopic screening can be avoided..

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Ogilive syndrome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Although the exact mechanism is not established, excess sympathetic tone( sympathetic overriding the parasympathetic) has been considered as a probable mechanism.
