Isolated liver metastases from colon cancer should be treated emergently with both chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
All perforated colon cancers are considered T4
N2 refers to involvement of greater than 4 regional lymph nodes

questions.text: Which of the following statements about colonic ca is untrue
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Liver metastases of colorectal ca can be managed by CT and hepatic resection but there is not much role of radiation therapy in these .

questions.text: The procedure shown in the following figure is done for ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Serial transverse enteroplasty (STEP) is a surgical procedure used primarily in the treatment of short bowel syndrome (SBS). In STEP, by making cuts in the intestine and creating a zigzag pattern, surgeons lengthen the amount of bowel available to absorb nutrients. Another procedure for Short bowel syndrome is Bianchi Procedure : The Bianchi Procedure is a surgery in which the bowel is cut in half longitudinally (down its length) and then one end is sewn to the other as shown in figure below.

questions.text: What has been shown in the following figure ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The caecum is most frequently a retroperitoneal structure, and therefore not susceptible to twisting. However, in up to 20% of individuals there is congenital incomplete peritoneal covering of the caecum with formation of a 'mobile' caecum on a mesentery, such that it no longer lies in the right iliac fossa. This is a normal variant but is associated with increased incidence of folding or twisting of the caecum (caecal volvulus), which may be complicated by obstruction, vascular compromise, or perforation. On Xray it shows up as a comma shaped caecum . Sigmoid Volvulus: The coffee-bean sign (also known as the kidney bean sign or bent inner tube sign ) is a sign on an abdominal plain radiograph of a sigmoid volvulus although some authors have also used the term to refer to closed loop small bowel obstructions.

questions.text: A 1-day-old female infant has a mass protruding through her umbilicus. Physical examination reveals an umbilical hernia. A CT scan reveals that part of another organ is attached to the inner surface of the hernia. What portion of the gastrointestinal tract is most likely to be attached to the inner surface of the umbilical hernia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The ileum is the most common site of Meckel’s diverticulum. This outpouching is a persistence of the vitelline duct and it can be attached to the umbilicus. The other choices are not correlated with the vitelline duct and therefore will not result in the condition discussed here.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever and a high white blood cell count. He reports having suffered a small stab wound in his back a few months ago. Because it was a shallow wound, he did not seek medical attention. The physician states that he has a retroperitoneal infection. Which of the following structures is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Descending colon is retroperitoneal structure while the other structures mentioned above are intraperitoneal structures.

questions.text: 25-year-old woman in the 8th month of pregnancy went to the outpatient clinic for her prenatal checkup. Ultrasound examination of the fetus showed part of the small bowel herniating into the amniotic cavity due to failure of fusion of the lateral folds in the abdominal region. Which condition is this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gastroschisis is the herniation of abdominal viscera as a result of failure of fusion of the anterior abdominal wall. This is more common on the right side. It is not covered by an amniotic layer in contrast to an omphalocele.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is in surgery for a ruptured appendix. A midline incision was made for greater access to the peritoneal cavity. The surgeon noted a 2-inch long finger-like pouch on the anterior border of the ileum about 2 feet away from the ileocecal junction. This is a remnant of which developmental structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Meckel’s diverticulum is remnant of the omphalomesenteric duct and is present two feet from the ileocaecal junction in 2% of the population and is 2 inches long.

choices.text: Chemotherapy + radiotherapy is the treatment of choice
Most common vessels to be involved which preclude surgery are proximal SMA and renal arteries

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and fullness. A CT scan was done which was suggestive of a retroperitoneal mass and a diagnosis of retroperioneal sarcoma was made. What is false regarding the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Retroperitoneal sarcomas are rare tumours accounting for only 1–2% of all solid malignancies (10–20% of all sarcomas are retroperitoneal). The peak incidence is in the fifth decade of life. The most frequently encountered cell types are:liposarcoma ,leiomyosarcoma, malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) Patients with sarcomas present late, because these tumours arise in the large potential spaces of the retroperitoneum and can grow very large without producing symptoms. Moreover, when symptoms do occur, they are non-specific, such as abdominal pain and fullness. Detailed multiplanar imaging (CT + MRI) with reconstructions is required not only for tumour detection, staging and surgical planning, but also for guiding percutaneous or surgical biopsy of these tumours. Such biopsies have a greater role than for other sarcomas. The definitive treatment of primary retroperitoneal sarcomas is surgical resection. Chemotherapy and radiotherapy without surgical debulking have rarely been beneficial, when used alone or in combination. The most common types of vascular involvement precluding resection are involvement of the proximal superior mesenteric vessels or involvement of bilateral renal vessels.

choices.text: A foreign body in the fistula tract.
Downstream obstruction of the fistulized segment of intestine.

questions.text: The failure of an enterocutaneous fistula to heal on a regimen of total parenteral nutrition and antisecretory therapy may be due to which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Factors which prevent healing of an enterocutaneous fistula include foreign body, epithelialization of the fistula tract, downstream obstruction, radiation enteritis, associated infection (abscess or sepsis), malignancy, and a short (

choices.text: More than eight bowel movements per day

questions.text: A 19-year-old man with medically refractory ulcerative colitis undergoes a total colectomy with J-pouch creation. What are some of the late complications of ileal pouch anal reconstruction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The functional outcome of ileal pouch-anal reconstruction is not always perfect. Patients should be counselled to expect 8 to 10 bowel movements per day. Up to 50% have some degree of nocturnal incontinence. Pouchitis occurs in nearly 50% of patients who undergo the operation for chronic ulcerative colitis, and small bowel obstruction is common. Pouches fail in 5 to 10% of patients.

choices.text: Lack of dietary fiber causes smaller stools volume requiring higher intraluminal pressure.
Chronic contraction causes muscular hypertrophy and causes colon to act as segments rather than a continuous tube.
The mucosa and muscularis mucosa herniate through the colon wall.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the ED with fever, abdominal pain, and bloody stools or the past 2 days. On CT scan he is found to have diverticulitis with scant free air and a small fluid collection associated with the sigmoid colon. What is the etiology of diverticulosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The majority of colonic diverticula are false diverticula in which the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated through the colonic wall. These diverticula occur between the taeniae coli, at points where the main blood vessels penetrate the colonic wall (presumably creating an area of relative weakness in the colonic muscle). They are thought to be pulsion diverticula resulting from high intraluminal pressure.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the ED with a 2-day history of left lower quadrant abdominal pain and is found to be febrile to 38.6°C. Her white blood cell (WBC) count is 15,000. On CT scan she is found to have colonic inflammation with an associated pericolic abscess. What is her Hinchey stage?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The Hinchey staging system is often used to describe the severity of complicated diverticulitis: Stage I includes colonic inflammation with an associated pericolic abscess; stage II includes colonic inflammation with a retroperitoneal or pelvic abscess; stage III is associated with purulent peritonitis; and stage IV is associated with faecal peritonitis.

questions.text: 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of the sensation of urinating air. He has a history of diverticulitis, with his last episode requiring hospitalization being 6 months ago. What are the most common fistulas that develop in complicated diverticulitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Approximately 5% of patients with complicated diverticulitis develop fistulas between the colon and an adjacent organ. Colovesical fistulas are most common, followed by colovaginal and coloenteric fistulas. Colocutaneous fistulas are a rare complication of diverticulitis.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man undergoes a screening colonoscopy and is found to have a polyp in his sigmoid colon. Which type of polyp is most associated with malignancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The risk of malignant degeneration is related to both the size and type of polyp. Villous adenomas may harbour cancer in up to 40%. Tubulovillous adenomas are at intermediate risk (22%).

choices.text: Right hemicolectomy, involved omentum, and as many of the peritoneal masses you can.
Right hemicolectomy with arterial supply and as many nodes as you can.
Right hemicolectomy with arterial supply, at least 12 nodes, the involved omentum, and resectable liver masses.
Don’t do a colon resection as the patient has distant metastases and should be diverted for palliation

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the ED with a 2-month history of nausea, emesis, 20-lb weight loss, and worsening diarrhea until 4 days ago, when he stopped passing flatus and having bowel movements. A CT scan shows a large obstructing right colon mass that may be involving the omentum with two liver lesions. What should be resected in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The objective in treatment of carcinoma of the colon is to remove the primary tumour along with its lymphovascular supply. Because the lymphatics of the colon accompany the main arterial supply, the length of bowel resected depends on which vessels are supplying the segment involved with the cancer. Any adjacent organ or tissue, such as the omentum, that has been invaded should be resected en bloc with the tumor. If the metastatic disease is low volume (isolated or potentially resectable liver lesions) and the resection of the primary tumor is straight forward (segmental abdominal colectomy), it is probably reasonable to proceed with resection. On the other hand, if the metastatic disease is high volume (carcinomatosis), especially if the primary tumor is minimally symptomatic, the operation should be aborted in order to facilitate early systemic chemotherapy.

questions.text: While reviewing pathology of a recent laparoscopic appendectomy, in addition to acute appendicitis, the patient had a 1.5-cm carcinoid tumor located at the base of the appendix. The patient is otherwise healthy and recovering well from surgery. What would you recommend?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Appendiceal carcinoid is one of the most common neoplasms to identify in an appendectomy specimen. Lesions that are Lesions larger than 1 or 2 cm, involving the appendiceal base or with lymph node metastasis or mesenteric invasion warrant right hemicolectomy. A radical appendectomy is not a described operation and adjuvant chemotherapy could be considered but only after definitive surgical care

questions.text: A 23-year-old thin woman with a history of surgical correction of her scoliosis is evaluated for symptoms of postprandial epigastric pain, fullness, nausea, and vomiting. Her physical examination is unremarkable except for her thin physique/stature. Barium upper GI series showed a dilated duodenum and stomach with minimal flow of barium into the jejunum. Which of the following is the operative management of choice for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The patient in this scenario has compression of the third portion of the duodenum by the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) as it passes over it. This rare condition is known as SMA syndrome or Wilkie syndrome. This syndrome is usually seen in young asthenic females with predisposing conditions of weight loss, scoliosis or corrective surgery for it, supine mobilization, and placement of a body cast. The diagnosis is usually made with either a barium upper GI series or a CT, with oral and intravenous (IV) contrast enhancement demonstrating a dilated duodenum and stomach with an abrupt or nearly complete cutoff of contrast agent at the third portion of the duodenum and minimal flow into the jejunum. Conservative management consisting of nutritional supplementation can be tried initially. In patients who fail medical management, the operative treatment of choice is duodenojejunostomy

choices.text: Anastomotic leakage with an enterocutaneous fistula

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman had a right hemicolectomy for villous adenoma of the cecum. Five days after surgery her surgical wound becomes red and tender. She underwent pelvic radiation therapy 5 years ago for cervical cancer. The surgeon opens her wound with immediate drainage of purulent fluid. The drainage persists as a continuous brown liquid discharge over the next day. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Most fistulas are iatrogenic and result from anastomotic leakage, inadvertent injury to the bowel during the operation, laceration of the bowel during an abdominal closure, or retained foreign bodies. Less than 2% of fistulas are the result of diseased bowel. When they are, the most common contributing factors are preoperative radiation therapy, intestinal obstruction, and inflammatory bowel disease. Although small bowel fistulas occasionally lead to generalized peritonitis, they most commonly produce a walled-off abscess manifested as an infection of the operative incision. The initial drainage may be purulent, but if the infection is caused by anastomotic leakage of the small bowel, the drainage becomes enteric within 1 to 2 days.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. On examination, the abdomen is tender, and there are no bowel sounds. An abdominal X-ray shows multiple air-fluid levels. What is the next best step in the management of this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Upper GI contrast study 1. Key Features in the Scenario: o Bilious vomiting in a neonate is a surgical emergency, often indicative of intestinal obstruction. o Intestinal malrotation with volvulus is the primary concern in this age group. 2. Investigation of Choice: o An upper GI contrast study is the gold standard for diagnosing malrotation and volvulus. o Findings include an abnormal position of the duodenojejunal (DJ) junction and corkscrew appearance of the bowel. 3. Management: o If volvulus is confirmed, emergent exploratory laparotomy (D) is required. o Observation (A) is inappropriate for bilious vomiting. o Contrast enema (B) is used for lower intestinal obstruction, e.g., Hirschsprung's disease.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension, failure to pass meconium, and bilious vomiting. On abdominal X-ray, there is evidence of dilated loops of bowel and a ground-glass appearance in the lower abdomen. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Meconium ileus 1. Key Features in the Scenario: o Failure to pass meconium, bilious vomiting, and abdominal distension are hallmark signs of intestinal obstruction in neonates. o The ground-glass appearance on X-ray is characteristic of meconium ileus, caused by thick, inspissated meconium obstructing the ileum. 2. Differential Diagnoses: o Hirschsprung’s disease (A): Presents with delayed meconium passage, but X-ray shows a transition zone, not ground-glass appearance. o Duodenal atresia (C): Bilious vomiting with a "double-bubble" sign on X-ray. o Necrotizing enterocolitis (D): Premature neonates with pneumatosis intestinalis on imaging. 3. Association: o Meconium ileus is strongly associated with cystic fibrosis. 4. Management: o Initial management involves nasogastric decompression, IV fluids, and imaging confirmation. o Therapeutic contrast enema may resolve the obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific diagnostic imaging modality for meconium ileus in a neonate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Contrast enema 1. Key Features in the Diagnosis: o A contrast enema is the most specific test for diagnosing meconium ileus. It shows the microcolon and filling defects caused by inspissated meconium in the ileum. 2. Other Modalities: o Abdominal X-ray (B): Shows non-specific findings like dilated loops of bowel and ground-glass appearance. o Abdominal ultrasound (A): May show dilated bowel loops but is less specific. o Upper GI contrast study (D): Used for upper GI obstructions like malrotation or volvulus, not meconium ileus. 3. Management Role: o The contrast enema is diagnostic and may also be therapeutic by loosening the thick meconium.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain out of proportion to physical findings. His abdomen is soft with no guarding or rigidity, and bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated lactate levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Acute mesenteric ischemia 1. Key Features in the Scenario: o Sudden, severe abdominal pain that is disproportionate to physical findings is highly suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI). o History of atrial fibrillation increases the risk of an embolism causing mesenteric artery occlusion. o Elevated lactate levels indicate tissue ischemia. 2. Differential Diagnoses: o Acute pancreatitis (A): Pain is severe and radiates to the back, often with elevated serum amylase/lipase. o Perforated peptic ulcer (B): Pain with guarding, rigidity, and free air under the diaphragm on imaging. o Small bowel obstruction (D): Cramping pain with distension, vomiting, and air-fluid levels on imaging. 3. Management: o Early recognition is critical; diagnosis is confirmed with CT angiography. o Prompt surgical or endovascular intervention is required.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for acute mesenteric ischemia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CT angiography 1. CT Angiography: o CT angiography is the gold standard for diagnosing acute mesenteric ischemia. It provides high-resolution images of blood flow and identifies occlusions, thrombi, or non-occlusive ischemia. 2. Other Imaging Modalities: o Abdominal ultrasound (A): Limited role due to bowel gas and poor visualization of mesenteric vessels. o Plain abdominal X-ray (B): May show non-specific findings like bowel distension or pneumatosis intestinalis (gas in the bowel wall). o MRI (D): Rarely used in emergencies due to time constraints.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, and significant weight loss over the past two months. She reports vomiting after meals and feels relieved when lying in the left lateral decubitus position. An upper GI contrast study reveals compression of the third part of the duodenum between the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and the aorta. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Wilkie’s syndrome 1. Key Features in the Scenario: o Symptoms of postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and relief in a specific position (left lateral decubitus or prone) are characteristic of Wilkie’s syndrome. o The compression of the third part of the duodenum between the SMA and aorta confirms the diagnosis. 2. Differential Diagnoses: o Peptic ulcer disease (A): Causes epigastric pain, typically relieved by food or antacids, but lacks postural relief. o Chronic pancreatitis (B): Causes pain radiating to the back, often with steatorrhea or diabetes. o Hirschsprung’s disease (D): Neonatal condition causing delayed meconium passage and constipation. 3. Management: o Initial treatment involves nutritional support, postural changes, and high-calorie diets to restore weight. o Severe cases may require surgical intervention (duodenojejunostomy).

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with chronic abdominal pain, weight loss, and intermittent diarrhea for the past 3 months. He also reports occasional episodes of low-grade fever and night sweats. On examination, there is abdominal distension and a palpable mass in the right iliac fossa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intestinal tuberculosis 1. Key Features in the Scenario: o Chronic abdominal pain, weight loss, fever, and a right iliac fossa mass are characteristic of intestinal tuberculosis (TB). o TB intestinal involvement is common at the ileocecal region due to the high lymphoid tissue concentration. 2. Differential Diagnoses: o Crohn’s disease (A): Mimics TB with chronic symptoms but often involves perianal disease or extraintestinal manifestations. o Carcinoma of the cecum (B): Presents with a right iliac fossa mass but lacks systemic symptoms like fever or night sweats. o Irritable bowel syndrome (D): Functional disorder without systemic features. 3. Management: o Confirm diagnosis with colonoscopy with biopsy (caseating granulomas) and/or gene Xpert for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. o Treatment is with anti-tubercular therapy (ATT).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of intestinal involvement in tuberculosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ileum and cecum 1. Anatomical Distribution: o The ileum and cecum are the most common sites affected in intestinal tuberculosis because of: ? High lymphoid tissue concentration (Peyer’s patches). ? Slower transit time allowing for bacterial colonization. 2. Differentiating Other Sites: o Duodenum (A) and jejunum (B): Rarely affected in TB. o Rectum (D): Uncommon sites, more typical for other diseases like ulcerative colitis or carcinoma. 3. Clinical Significance: o Knowledge of the common site helps direct imaging and biopsy for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of extensive small bowel resection due to mesenteric ischemia presents with chronic diarrhea and weight loss. His serum vitamin B12 levels are low. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Loss of ileal absorption The terminal ileum is the primary site for vitamin B12 and bile acid absorption. Patients with significant ileal resection often develop vitamin B12 deficiency and bile acid malabsorption, leading to chronic diarrhea. Loss of ileal absorption is a hallmark feature of SBS in such cases.

questions.text: A patient with Short Bowel Syndrome is started on parenteral nutrition due to severe malabsorption. Which of the following complications is the patient most at risk for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hepatic cholestasis Prolonged use of parenteral nutrition (PN) in SBS can lead to hepatic cholestasis, a condition caused by bile flow obstruction due to the absence of enteral feeding. This complication is more common in patients with long-term PN dependency.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of chronic hypertension and coronary artery disease presents with abdominal pain after eating and significant weight loss over the last 3 months. A CT angiography reveals narrowing of the mesenteric arteries. Which watershed area is most susceptible to ischemia in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Splenic flexure The splenic flexure is a classic watershed area of the colon, located at the junction of the territories supplied by the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). In conditions of decreased blood flow (e.g., mesenteric ischemia), this area is particularly vulnerable.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical scenarios is most likely to result in ischemic injury to watershed areas in the brain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Global cerebral hypoperfusion Watershed areas in the brain are regions between the major cerebral artery territories, such as the ACA-MCA and MCA-PCA border zones. These areas are particularly vulnerable to ischemic injury during global cerebral hypoperfusion, as seen in systemic hypotension or cardiac arrest.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male undergoes a colonoscopy, which reveals a 4 cm tumor in the sigmoid colon. A biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. CT scan shows tumor invasion into the pericolonic fat but no lymph node or distant metastasis. What is the TNM stage of this cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) T3 N0 M0 In the TNM staging system: • T3 indicates tumor invasion through the muscularis propria into pericolonic tissues. • N0 means no regional lymph node metastasis. • M0 indicates no distant metastasis. This combination classifies the cancer as Stage IIa in the AJCC staging system.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is diagnosed with colon cancer. Histopathological analysis reveals tumor invasion into the submucosa (T1) and metastasis in two regional lymph nodes (N1). There is no evidence of distant metastasis. What is the clinical stage of this cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stage IIIa According to the AJCC system: • T1 indicates invasion into the submucosa. • N1 (metastasis in 1-3 regional lymph nodes) places the cancer in the Stage III category. • For T1 with N1, the specific stage is Stage IIIa.
